reviewText:
I found this to be a very charming point-and-click adventure game.  The focus of the story is on a depressive child clown by the name of Sadwick, who departs from his family circus to avert the end of the world from coming to pass.

The story is more of a whimsical one, but the game is not a comedy and does take itself seriously.  You get a nice amount of character growth from Sadwick and the course of the story has you meet new and interesting characters in each scene along the way.  The amount of depth to each character you meet was pleasantly surprising, and at least a few really made for some happy smile-inducing moments and the German voice acting is quite expressive (see my note below) .  The environments are very beautifully drawn and in-game animations are very good too.  There are some cutscenes which have less polish, looking maybe more like a 90's cartoon but overall did not detract from the experience for me.  The music is quite good, even if some of the tracks are re-used a few too many times.

Game ran just fine, but doesn't alt-tab too well.  Saving, mouse controls, the GUI are all perfectly fine.  The game has no failstates, and you can hold Spacebar to highlight interactables.  This game does have a fair few number of puzzles that are not easy to intuit the solutions for, so you will likely have to resort to a guide more often than you'd like.  This is par for the course in adventure games, although the par is a bit high in this game.


I also wanted to address a few complaints I saw a lot in other people's reviews.

Performance : Many users complained of the game failing to launch, launching to a black screen, or crashing.  I never once had any such issue.  I hope others who do are able to resolve theirs.

Sadwick's walking speed : Some users complained that Sadwick walks too slow.  In most adventure games you can double-click on screen transitions to automatically trigger them.  You can do that in this game too, so its possible those users did not know.  Sadwick walks at a fine pace otherwise, no scene is especially large bar one and even then the transitions in that area are numerous.

Voice acting : I heard that the English dub VA for Sadwick is unbearable and whiny.  Given his personality in the game I could see why this might be, so I used the original German voice acting and enjoyed it thoroughly.  I have no problems with using the German VA.

Broken audio : Some users comment that audio seems to cut off abruptly at the end of some spoken lines.  I cannot comment on the English audio, but this is sometimes noticeable in the German audio. I did not find it common enough nor disruptive enough to say it was any significant detriment, although the developers should fix it if so.

Controls : Some users complain the game fails to register mouse clicks.  I never had this happen, but you do have to hold down the mouse button to open the small interaction menu.

Story : Some people just don't like the premise or character personality, or how the game ends.  That's fine, its just down to taste.  I enjoyed it, others will not.


All in all, I would recommend it.  I very much enjoyed myself.  About 10-12 hrs playtime.

reviewText:
tl;dr: Some really fantastic artwork and an interesting world with fun secondary characters to explore. That aside, this game misses too many marks to be really good, and becomes almost a chore towards the end, mostly due to the old bane of point & clicks: illogical puzzles and rushed final chapters.

It's a mostly melancholic story with great moments of bleak humour, one that promises to be interesting but loses steam along the way. There is some fun writing to be found in it (I do love me some Talking Rocks and any and all quips they feel like making are fine by me), but the story becomes weirdly convoluted in the last chapter. The world building is fascinating nonetheless, and along with the gorgeous art they are clearly the highlights of the experience. As for the english voice over, it has some bad moments but it's mostly alright. The hero's voice may take some getting used to though.

For me the major let down is that too many of the puzzles are really unintuitive and illogical, and there is only that much drudgery I'm willing to accept in my play. I don't care if that was fine when Lucas Arts did it, it isn't fine now, especially not if you expect me to traverse multiple screens with a really slow character to try out totally random things that follow no internal logic whatsoever. It gets worse as the chapters progress, and by the last one you'll have too many moments of being hard pressed to figure out what to do next without immense patience or a walkthrough. Any guidance, even subtle indications, would have helped, but they are as lacking as any type of a hint system.

On a positive note, if you were worried about bugs the Special Edition" seems to have taken care of most of the previous problems. Just bear in mind that this is an older game so there are limited resolutions offered - expect black bars if you have a wide screen. High DPI displays will also need to disable display scaling to be able to play in fullscreen.

So would I suggest it?
Probably not. I'm usually a sucker for projects of love even if they end up being lovable trainwrecks

Short version: 79%An interesting point ‘n’ click adventure game with a bunch of unique ideas and almost painfully broken controls. Whispered World is probably not the greatest game released by Daedalic Entertainment, but if you like stories which set up everything for the last five minutes, then it’s a must-have.

Long version:The Whispered World is an interesting specimen. At first it seems like a usual old-style point ‘n’ click adventure, where the plot is large suppressed by the depressingly pessimistic attitude of the protagonist. On top of that, the story introduces a lot of seemingly unconnected and strange elements at every turn, which usually don’t lead anywhere in particular. Until you get to the very end and realise Whispered World is like movies such as Usual Suspects or Sixth Sense: everything was just a very long setup for the final huge twist.
Is it a good twist at least? It’s hard to tell. To some degree it’s predictable and clichéd. On the other hand it is a bittersweet ending that fits the overall tone.

The seemingly unconnected aspects of the plot translate into a fairly challenging puzzle system, where the role of items and hotspots are not always (or always not) obvious. This leads to a fair share of trial and error scenarios, especially in the last third the story, where everything gets increasingly surreal.

From a technical standpoint, the game has a few problems, like disturbingly choppy animations and sluggish, somewhat unresponsive controls. Many people also suffer from audio sync problems. These shortcomings won’t make it unplayable, but they may result in some unneeded frustration that could have been averted with a little more care.

reviewText:
Before I begin in earnest, I'll give this caveat: It is absolutely imperative that you turn off the audio for the dialogue in this game. The person they employed to voice the protagonist delivers, bar none, the absolute worst performance I have ever experienced in a game within this or any other genre. It's not just a case of it being weird or unconvincing (though make no mistake - it is both weird and unconvincing) - it's a case of it actually inducing physical pain via headaches. It is whiny, grating, nasal, and draws out every vowel for about twice as long as it should. It is Woody Allen mach 10. It is so unbelievably terrible that it took me four years between buying the game when it first came out and finishing it today, as in my first play session I found Sadwick's voice so utterly loathsome that I uninstalled the game and forgot it even existed until the Special Edition popped up in my library out of leftfield.

So, with that said, is the game worth playing? The answer to this question is a heavily qualified 'yes'. The hype that built up around The Whispered World in the lead-up to its release was, in my estimation, completely unmerited, but it's a good enough game.

Much has been made of the lack of logic in the game's puzzles, though in my experience only a half dozen or so had a 'How in God's name did they expect me to know that?' solution. While moments like this are infuriating and speak to anachronistic game design, if you're prepared to just consult a walkthrough when you're hopelessly stuck, attribute the momentary catapults into the sky of stupidity to infrequent acid flashbacks on the designer's behalf, and then just carry on resituated on our beloved terra firma, they're not intolerable. In my estimation most of the puzzles are actually amongst the better within the genre, but some may just have a single step which is complete nonsense, or, worse yet, actively go against what Sadwick intimates you should do with an object in his 'hint' dialogue.

Divorced from the godawful voice acting, the writing is actually pretty decent and on a few, rare occasions genuinely funny. The plot employs a stock standard three act structure (albeit spread over four): get quest, get delayed, complete quest. It brings nothing new to the table in this respect, but it's serviceable.

My primary criticism of The Whispered World is the world itself. The hand drawn art is certainly pretty, if somewhat lacking in vibrancy, but the world itself is just dead. It's quiet, depopulated, and dull. The Asgil, which are meant to be an impossibly fearsome threat to everything good, are two guys. No more. Two guys - the boss and the bumbling underling. A halfway prepared opposition could take these guys out with slingshots and peas. That would be if the world's regular inhabitants who might form this opposition weren't similarly scarce. Most acts introduce no more than three new characters, whom you never really need to speak to more than twice (albeit at some considerable, and arguably unnecessary length). I didn't really care for the story of this depressive clown prophesied to destroy the world, because it was a world I found impossible to become invested in. It's not so much a world as a series of tableauxs, connected with varying degrees of success. My sole motivation to persevere was to find the next puzzle. And as an addendum, I also found the ending to be a self-consciously sentimental attempt to lend this rather small and unambitious story an unearned sense of epic, emotional gravitas. It's not signposted in any way, and really just feels cheap, but I guess your mileage may vary on this.

If you're a hardcore adventure game enthusiast, by all means give TWW a shot, but that's really the only audience that would truly enjoy this game, because the state of the genre over the past decade or two has turned us into a rather forgiving lot. I'd advise anyone else to steer well clear.

(I originally played this offline, so my listed playtime is not accurate.)

I fell in love with Daedalic Entertainment after playing the Deponia trilogy. If I had to select Daedalic's masterpiece, however, I think I would select The Whispered World. It has a poignant, introspective storyline, beautiful art, a plaintive soundtrack, and engaging gameplay. The game is not perfect--there are a few places where the plot drags, for example--but overall it is fun and thought-provoking. The puzzles are challenging but fun, and most can be approached very logically. What is truly great about The Whispered World, however, is its mind-blowing ending--really, this game must be played to completion. I can't recommend this game highly enough, especially if you are a fan of point-and-click adventures.

Some people find the voice of the main character Sadwick annoying or even unbearable. Personally, I wouldn't call his voice pleasant but I don't find it particularly irritating, and the quality of the acting is quite good. Certainly don't let it stop you from enjoying this beautiful game. On which note, Daedalic is a German company, but they have first-rate translators--one would rarely know that the game is a translation.

reviewText:
I've got some mixed feelings here. The Whispered World isn't the greatest point-and-click adventure game I've played, but ultimately it's a solid game that handles its story, characters, and themes really well and features acceptable, if challenging, puzzle mechanics.


The best element of the game by far is its character development: specifically, the way the game develops its protagonist, Sadwick. To put it simply, Sadwick is utterly unlikeable when you begin the game. Picture a combination of Jeffery Dallas from the Julian Smith videos and Marvin the Depressed Robot from Hitchhiker's Guide--except that his complaining, self-absorbtion, and misery are all treated unironically, and not as a source of humor. He writes bad poetry about his feelings, sobs over his rotten circumstances, and loses his temper at his lovably senile grandfather. But while the game doesn't treat Sadwick's disposition mockingly, it also doesn't take him too seriously. Sadwick isn't an existential hero fighting helplessly against tragic circumstances. He's just an ornery kid with a lousy life who responds the way any self-interested person might.

As the game goes on, however, Sadwick slowly and subtly transforms to the point that you are genuinely concerned with his wellbeing and with the success of his quest. Where other characters inertly accept the coming end-of-the-world scenario at the center of the game's story, Sadwick steps up and tries to change things, certain as he is at first that his actions will prove pointless. The further into the game you go, the less gloomy and caustic Sadwick becomes. And as he grows in confidence--or at least determination--he becomes a truly sympathetic character. By the game's end, I loved the little guy.

The game's other characters are more of a mixed bag. Some, such as Grandpa, are quite lovable, while others, such as Bobby (the King's messenger) and Loucaux (the main villain) can be rather unlikeable or one-dimensional. The characters from the game's second section are my favorite. The sleep-deprived landowner Ruben and his loud, enthusiastic servant Bando form the perfect odd couple and are also the most objectively interesting characters in the game.

reviewText:
The Whispered World is a wondefully drawn game let down by lackluster voice acting, some illogical puzzles and a disappointing ending.

This is a point and click adventure in the traditional sense, it doesn't really try to innovate or stray away from the genre in any way. The only thing slightly unusual is that you have a pet creature following you around, which can also transform into different forms. And that regularly comes into play when trying to solve puzzles, thank goodness too because there are a lot of fun interactions made possible by this.

So what are the primary components of a traditional style point and click game? Well, that would be the story, the setting, the art, the dialogue, the voice acting and the puzzles. The parts where this game does well would be the art and the dialogue. The story and the setting show much more promise in the beginning, however as things start to unravel so does the strength of the writing.

That leaves us with the voice acting and the puzzles. Except for the main protagonist I wouldn't say the voice acting is especially bad, it is merely let down by bad editing. Plenty has been said by others of the main protagonist and his annoying voice acting, perhaps it was even intentional, but it is bad design to make him so when it serves no story purpose. The puzzle design varies greatly, some puzzles are illogical and appear to exist merely to frustrate the player, while others make use of the tools presented to you in an intuitive and satisfying to solve way.

There are also some UI issues that plague the game, but as it is a very minimilastic game I can overlook them.
All in all, I recommend it to point & click adventure game enthusiast, however not to very many others.

6½ / 10

reviewText:
I discovered The Whispered World after beating all three Deponia titles and ending up plowing through Daedalic's game catalog. This title struck out and I decided to purchase it due to the abundance of positive reviews. I had a nice time completing The Whispering World, but I expected more. The game is mediocre at best, containing certain pros and cons that end up making for a experience that is only memorable due to it's unexpected ending. Basically, it functions as a normal point&click game, this one being set in a fantasy world full of queer creatures and interesting places to visit and explore.
The art design is a positive aspect of this title, with original scenarios and striking detail existing in them. However, the low resolution at which the game runs can lower the bar for some gamers.
The achievements are easily obtainable and take, at maximum two playthroughs to complete them.
Negatively, a hint system or something related would be appreciated. Countless times did I get stuck and had to look for a playthrough in order to continue the main quest. Also, the voice acting is of a poor-medium quality. Sadwick himself proves, after hours of hearing him talk, to have an annoying voice, something that can be game breaking for some.
TWW does not offer any reason to replay it's main story, besides an achievement or two. The story is not good nor as it is bad. Just don't get your hopes up. The usage of Spot, Sadwick's pet, is original and distinguishes the game from other point&click titles. I did not have any problems running TWW, no crashes nor black screens. Many players report those problems, so beware of that.

All and all, I do recommend The Whispering World to the average point&click gamer. It can be an enjoyable title and besides, a sequel is in the works.

reviewText: I was pretty impressed with this game, of course the best thing about it is the aestethics. It has gorgeous animation and environment which looks like a fully animated feauture. The artistic theme of Fall colors are present from beginning to end and it ties in nicely with the overall tone and story. As for the actual gameplay it is pretty standard adventure game fare, if you've played any of the classic Sierra or Lucas Arts point and click adventures from the 90's especially later titles like The Curse Of Monkey Island you know what to expect. For the most part the puzzles are simple enough but then sometimes you run into that one puzzle that just kinda stops you in your steps and you're forced to switch to a strategy of trial and error. Depending on your abilities some puzzles can be pretty hard to figure out. However that aside the soundtrack, artwork and story really is worth the price of admission on their own and this game has ended up being one of my favorite entries in the genre. Even better, with the special edition a lot of the technical game breaking issues have been fixed so if you were put off from buying this game because of the bugs in the original version (which all owners of the original version seem to have received for free since then) rest assured that this game works just fine and makes for an enjoyable experience.

The Whispered World is by no means a bad game. In fact it's actually a really good game, with some exceptional faults that destroy the rest of the magic.

The game is a delight to view, the hand rendered backgrounds are exceptional and even the pen and line animations are good, if slightly halting at times. The cutscenes suffer a little as they pull completely from the Disney style animation and lack the richer background texture and colour palette.

The music is also a delight, and fits the fantastic world well, with soft natural tones that play quietly in the background and aren't a distraction at all. As for the voice acting, it was fairly bad. The narrator (Sadwick's voice) is nasal and annoying, to the point of being so annoying that I simply ended up turning the sound off and played by reading the subtitles. That said albeit it being annoying, the catch is the voice is a perfect one to suit the pessimistic, morose main character.

Now coming to the characterisation, Daedalic seem to enjoy taking unlikable unlikely hero's and making them the protagonists (Rufus in Deponia). Sadwick continues this trend, he complains, and generally acts like a complete misanthrope, to the exasperation of not only his circus family, who deny him doing anything as he invariably messes it up  and himself. It's a difficult character to make a protagonist, as games require an active character, willing to undertake quests and action. As an unwilling character Sadwick seems forced" and it makes him most difficult to identify with

So I actually enjoyed this game. It's got great aspects for a standard point and click advanture, but just has a bunch of issues in there. I'll probably try the next game from Whispered World, but you need to know these things before you play:

1. You won't be able to listen to the english voice acting, it's unbearable. It's an extreme amount better with german audio and english subtitles. Much more enjoyable. That's how I played through this.

-Beautiful background art

-Well done character design and animation

-A fitting soundtrack albeit not super memorable

The achievements aren't too demanding, but you should check the achievement guide before starting, because some you may have to do a second run to get if you don't do it right.

reviewText:
Two things initially led me to this title. Having just completed the strangely compelling Broken Age, which wistfully plunged me right back into classic adventure gaming, I was now primed for more quality point and clicking. Then I saw the excellent trailer for The Whispered World's upcoming sequel, Silence. I was sold.

Some nice in-game animations and elegant background art make this game mostly enjoyable for the eyes. The carefully crafted hand-drawn environments are all of uncompromising high quality, sometimes with an air of Discworldness charm. The overall visual quality is immediately appealing.

The game's most disheartening facet is unfortunately reason alone to completely soil the entire experience: Sadwick is an immeasurably insupportable lead character. His unlikeable depressed loser personality shows very few redeeming qualities and, from memory, bears no comparable equivalent in the long history of comically incompetent protagonists. However, this is still nothing compared to his especially unbearable voice. Why the developer chose to ruin an otherwise decent game with such grating performance and amateur voice direction is beyond reason.

Uneven dialogue quality often turns into boring overdrawn segments and repeats unnecessarily. An annoying audio glitch cuts off the beginning of every single line, resulting in characters that appear not to take a breath in between sentences. It is not all bad - there are a few interesting characters and situations, but they get lost in the affair's global tediousness.

Interactions feel dated: the player pointlessly grabs anything in sight, often without prior insight to its possible future use, and tries to combine items more or less logically to complete puzzles. Sure, that's old school adventuring, but the game does a poor job of guiding the player subtly or making you feel smart when completing objectives. Most glaring is the illogical use of Spot, the hero's inexplicably shape-shifting pet, which feels like a tacked-on solution for puzzles that otherwise make little sense.

To top it off the game kept crashing several times towards the end, coupled with very buggy click registrations that gave it a sense of poor technical quality.

There is no telling how much I wanted to like The Whispered World. I really did, but that feeling rapidly transformed into an eagerness to get it over with and move on to something better.

There is no telling how much I wanted to like The Whispered World. I really did, but that feeling rapidly transformed into an eagerness to get it over with and move on to something better.

reviewText:
I'm frustrated. This game is fun, has some decent puzzles (and some slightly obtuse ones), and pushes the limits on item-combining shenanigans, providing unique responses to almost every combination I tried. I liked the art style and was charmed by the complicated ideas it presented, as well as drawn to the nihilistic, cowardly, and deceitful Sadwick. I wasn't bothered much by the minor clicking glitches, too absorbed in doing everything possible to try to save or maybe destroy this world I got sucked into.

But then. The ending. The kind of an ending this got can work sometimes, if there's a sufficient buildup or a particularly engaging message. But this time, it just felt like nonsense, completely invalidating my investment in the game. I can't help but be pretty disappointed. All of the questions raised, like if there can be a stagnation-induced stability, or whether you could fight fate, or what the world's state means and why the people in power aren't fixing it, these questions are all dismissed in favor of some new character I have no reason to care about.

Still, the enjoyment in the rest of the game was good enough for me to recommend it, though I'd try to wait for a sale if possible.
